variant.question: Lights on and in the vicinity of aerodromes may be turned off, provided that they can be again brought into operation :

options.text: At least one hour before the expected arrival of an aircraft
At least 5 minutes before the expected arrival of an aircraft
At least 30 minutes before the expected arrival of an aircraft
At least 15 minutes before the expected arrival of an aircraft

variant.question: Lights on and in the vicinity of aerodromes may be turned off, provided that they can be again brought into operation:

options.text: at least one hour before the expected arrival of an aircraft.
at least 15 minutes before the expected arrival of an aircraft.
at least 5 minutes before the expected arrival of an aircraft.
at least 30 minutes before the expected arrival of an aircraft.

variant.question: A separation minimum shall be applied between a light or MEDIUM aircraft and a HEAVY aircraft and between a LIGHT aircraft and a MEDIUM aircraft when the heavier aircraft is making a low or missed approach and the lighter aircraft is landing on the same runway in the opposite direction or on a parallel opposite direction runway separated by :

options.text: Less than 760 m
Less than 730 m

variant.question: A separation minimum shall be applied between a LIGHT or MEDIUM aircraft and a HEAVY aircraft and between a LIGHT aircraft and a MEDIUM aircraft when the heavier aircraft is making a low or missed approach and the lighter aircraft is landing on the same runway in the opposite direction or on a parallel opposite direction runway separated by

options.text: less than 760 m.
less than 730 m.
is performed when either part or all of an instrument approach procedure is not completed and the approach is executed in visual reference to terrain.
can be performed during IFR approaches, if the cloud base is 1 000 ft higher than the appropriate DA or MDA for that procedure.
can be performed during IFR approaches, if the cloud base is 1 000 ft higher than the appropriate DA or MDA for that procedure, and the visibility is at least 5.5 km.
can be performed during IFR and VFR approaches in VMC.

variant.question: When ATC issues taxi clearances, they always specify a clearance limit. At this point, the aircraft has to stop, unless it has previously received further clearance to proceed beyond that point. Which of the following statements regarding taxi instructions is correct?

options.text: When a taxi clearance takes the aircraft beyond a runway, the clearance shall include explicit instructions to either cross the runway, or hold short of that runway.
No controller would ever issue a taxi clearance that takes the aircraft to a clearance limit which involves crossing a runway.
Whenever taxi instructions require an aircraft to cross a runway, the clearance will state explicitly to hold short of that runway.
Even if the clearance limit is beyond a runway, taxi instructions never include a clearance to cross that runway.
an instrument approach where the pilot has the option to continue the approach visually, providing that he has the necessary visual criteria.
any part of an instrument approach that is carried out in VMC.
an approach made under VFR using height and track guidance.
the circling part of a precision approach to a runway other than the runway on which the landing is to be made.

variant.question: According to Annex 6, what is the definition of Required Navigation Performance (RNP)?

options.text: A statement of the navigation performance necessary for operation within a defined airspace.
A statement of the navigation performance required during a pilot skill test.
A statement of the navigation performance necessary during flight tests for a new aircraft type.
A statement of the navigation performance required when installing a new navigation aid on the ground.

variant.question: What does the term "CLEARANCE LIMIT" mean?

options.text: The time after which air traffic control clearance will be automatically cancelled if the flight has not been commenced.
The time of expiry of air traffic control clearance.
The time at which aircraft is given an air traffic control clearance.
The point to which aircraft is granted an air traffic control clearance.

variant.question: What does the term "CLEARANCE LIMIT" mean?

options.text: The point to which aircraft is granted an air traffic control clearance.
The time at which aircraft is given an air traffic control clearance.
The time of expiry of air traffic control clearance.
The time after which air traffic control clearance will be automatically cancelled if the flight has not been commenced.

variant.question: Which of the following elements shall be included in an ATIS message that contains both arrival and departure information?

options.text: Altimeter setting(s).
Significant taxiway surface conditions.
Surface wind direction (in degrees true).
Transition altitude.
FIC and ATS
FIR and SAR
AMS and ATS
FIC and SAR

variant.question: In which situation would a METAR result in a prompt ATIS update?

options.text: When receiving a METAR SPECI.
When receiving of any official weather, regardless of content change or reported values.
Only when the ceiling and/or visibility changes by a significant value.
Every 30 minutes if weather conditions are below those for VFR (otherwise every 60 minutes).

variant.question: In which situation would a METAR result in a prompt ATIS update?

options.text: When receiving a MET REPORT SPECIAL.
Only when the ceiling and/or visibility changes by a significant value.
When receiving of any official weather, regardless of content change or reported values.
Every 30 minutes if weather conditions are below those for VFR (otherwise every 60 minutes).

variant.question: The phases related to an aircraft in emergency or believed in emergency are:

options.text: Uncertainty phase, alert phase, distress phase.
Uncertainty phase, urgency phase, distress phase.
Uncertainty phase, distress phase, urgency phase.
Uncertainty phase, alert phase, distress phase and urgency phase.

variant.question: If no ICAO identifier has been attributed to an alternate airport (box 16) of a flight plan form:

options.text: write ZZZZ in box 16 and indicate in box 18 (additional information) ALTN/ followed by the name of the airport.
write XXXX in box 16 and indicate in box 18 (additional information) DEST/ followed by the name of the airport.
write ZZZZ in box 16 and indicate in box 18 (additional information) DEST/ followed by the name of the airport.
write XXXX in box 16 and indicate in box 18 (additional information) ALTN/ followed by the name of the airport.

variant.question: If no ICAO identifier has been attributed to an alternate airport (box 16) of a flight plan form:

options.text: Write ZZZZ in box 16 and indicate in box 18 (additional information) ALTN/followed by the name of the airport.
Write ZZZZ in box 16 and indicate in box 18 (additional information) DEGT/followed by the name of the airport.
Write XXXX in box 16 and indicate in box 18 (additional information) ALTN/followed by the name of the airport
Write XXXX in box 16 and indicate in box 18 (additional information) DEGT/followed by the name of the airport

variant.question: Why is fuel dumped during an emergency after take-off?

options.text: To get below maximum landing mass (MLM).
Lower risk of fire during landing.
To have a better airplane manoeuvrability and get back to the airport quickly for landing.
To not damage the runway while landing.
The short period oscillation should always be heavily damped.
When the phugoid is slightly unstable, an aeroplane becomes uncontrollable.
The phugoid should always be heavily damped.
A slightly unstable short period oscillation is no problem for an aeroplane.
VR must not be less than 1.05 VMCA and not less than V1.
VR must not be less than 1.05 VMCA and not less than 1.1 V1.
VR must not be less than 1.1 VMCA and not less than V1.
VR must not be less than VMCA and not less than 1.05 V1.
Oxygen diffusion from the blood into the cells depends on the partial oxygen pressure gradient.
The gradient of diffusion is higher at altitude than it is at sea level.
Oxygen is mainly transported in plasma.
Oxygen diffusion from the lungs into the blood is independent of the partial oxygen pressure.
V~R~ must not be less than 1.05 V~MCA~ and not less than V~1~.
V~R~ must not be less than 1.1 V~MCA ~and not less than V~1~.
V~R~ must not be less than V~MCA~ and not less than 1.05 V~1~.
V~R~ must not be less than 1.05 V~MCA~ and not less than 1.1 V~1~.
Spoiler extension increases the stall speed, the minimum rate of descent and the minimum angle of descent.
Flap extension reduces the maximum lift/drag ratio thus reducing the minimum rate of descent.
Flap extension reduces the stall speed, which increases the maximum glide distance.
Flap extension has no effect on the minimum rate of descent as this is only affected by TAS.
As the angle of attack increases, the stagnation point on the aerofoil's profile moves downwards on the profiles leading edge.
The stagnation point is always situated on the chord line, the centre of pressure is not.
The centre of pressure is the point on the aerofoil leading edge where the airflow splits up.
The stagnation point is another name for centre of pressure.
A **ridge** is an elongated area of relatively high pressure, a **trough** is a elongated area of relatively low pressure and a **col** is a region between two highs and two lows.
A **ridge** is an elongated area of relatively high pressure, a c**ol **is a elongated area of relatively low pressure and a **trough** is a region between two highs and two lows.
A **col **is an elongated area of relatively high pressure, a **trough** is a elongated area of relatively low pressure and a **ridge** is a region between two highs and two lows.
A **trough** is an elongated area of relatively high pressure, a **ridge** is a elongated area of relatively low pressure and a **col** is a region between two highs and two lows.
The climb limited take-off mass depends on pressure altitude and outer air temperature.
The performance limited take-off mass is the highest of: field length limited take-off mass climb limited take-off mass obstacle limited take-off mass.
The climb limited take-off mass will increase if the headwind component increases.
The climb limited take-off mass increases when a larger take-off flap setting is used.
Fog can be supercooled and can also contain ice crystals.
Mist and haze consist of water droplets.
Fog and haze do not occur in the tropics.
Mist and haze only differ by different values of visibility.
The lower limit of a TMA shall be established at a height of at least 700 ft AGL.
The upper limit of a CTR shall be established at a height of at least 3 000 ft AMSL.
The lower limit of a CTA shall be established at a height of at least 1 500 ft AGL.
The lower limit of an UIR may coincide with an IFR cruising level.
Flap extension causes a reduction in stall speed and the maximum glide distance.
Flap extension will increase (CL/CD)max thus causing a reduction in the minimum rate of descent.
Flap extension has no influence on the minimum rate of descent, as only TAS has to be taken into account.
Spoiler extension causes a reduction in stall speed and the minimum rate of descent, but increases the minimum descent angle.
Dynamic stability is possible only when the aeroplane is statically stable about the relevant axis.
A dynamically stable aeroplane would be almost impossible to fly manually.
Dynamic stability about the lateral axis implies that after being displaced from its original equilibrium condition, the aeroplane will return to that condition without oscillation.
Static stability means that the aeroplane is also dynamically stable about the relevant axis.
Problems in the personal relationships between crew members are likely to hamper the communication process.
Inconsistent communication improves flight safety.
Personal conflict that takes place prior to take-off should wait to be addressed until the end of the flight.
There is no relation between inadequate communication and incidents or accidents.
The Solar System consists of the Sun, planets and stars.
The planets move around the Sun like all stars of the Solar System.
The Earth is one of the planets which are all moving in elliptical orbit around the Sun.
The Sun moves in an elliptical orbit around the Earth.
The climb limited take-off mass depends on pressure altitude and outer air temperature.
The climb limited take-off mass will increase if the headwind component increases.
The performance limited take-off mass is the highest of field length limited take-off mass climb limited take-off mass obstacle limited take-off mass.
The climb limited take-off mass increases when a larger take-off flap setting is used.
During a phugoid altitude varies significantly, but during a short period oscillation it remains approximately constant.
During both a phugoid and a short period oscillation altitude remains approximately constant.
During both a phugoid and a short period oscillation altitude varies significantly.
During a phugoid altitude remains approximately constant, but during a short period oscillation it varies significantly.
The climb limited Take-off Mass depends on pressure altitude and outside air temperature.
The climb limited Take-off Mass increases when a larger take-off flap setting is used.
The climb limited Take-off Mass will increase if the headwind component increases.
Obstacle limited takeoff mass
Climb limited takeoff mass
Tyre speed limited takeoff mass
Field length limited takeoff mass
Extension of flaps causes a reduction of the stall speed, the maximum glide distance also reduces.
Extension of flaps has no influence on the minimum rate of descent, as only the TAS has to be taken into account.
Extension of flaps will increase (CL/CD MAX), causing the minimum rate of descent to decrease.
Spoiler extension decreases the stall speed and the minimum rate of descent, but increases the minimum descent angle.
Visual Meteorological conditions.
Very Marginal Conditions as broadcast by VOLMET.
Visibility Measurement Coefficient.
Vertical Mean Clearance.
Organised Track System.
Oceanic Traffic Separation.
Oceanic Track System.
Omni-directional Track Selector.
Aeronautical Fixed Service.
Aeronautical Forecast Service.
Aeronautical Fixed System.
Aircraft Fixed Station.

variant.question: Which of the following only lists instructions and information that should always be read back?

options.text: SSR code, QNH, take-off clearance, and speed instructions.
QNH, SSR code, and approach aid serviceability.
ATC clearance, speed instructions, and runway state information.
QNH, weather information, and runway-in-use.

variant.question: Which of the following is not an emergency frequency?

options.text: 2 182 kHz

variant.question: Which of the following is not an emergency frequency?

options.text: 243 kHz
243 MHz
